Chairman Meow
for Mayor

"A New Paw Forward."

Nightclub owner. Jazz patron. 14-hour nap advocate. The only candidate who has never once lied, because he is a cat and does not speak.

Read the Platform

The Chairman's Platform

Six Pillars. Four Paws.

üõèÔ∏è

Mandatory 16-Hour Nap Policy

All city employees will be entitled to 16 hours of mandatory rest per 24-hour cycle. The remaining 8 hours are optional. Productivity studies from the Chairman's own life show that napping 16 hours a day has never once prevented him from achieving his goals (knocking things off tables, yelling at 3 AM).

üê¶

A Bird in Every Window

$4.2 million in municipal funds will be redirected from road maintenance to installing bird feeders on every window in the city. "Infrastructure" has always meant "things to look at while sitting," and the Chairman will not be taking questions on this.

üö´

Defund the Vacuum

The city's $340,000 annual vacuum budget is state-sponsored terrorism. Chairman Meow will reallocate all vacuum-related spending to the new Department of Silence. Brooms are fine. Brooms know their place.

üé∑

24/7 Live Jazz

Every public building will have a live jazz band. The Chairman has already proven this model works at BASSLINE Nightclub, where The Whisker Quartet has been playing continuously since March 14, 2025. (Note: The Whisker Quartet is requesting this policy be removed. Request denied.)

üì¶

Universal Box Access

If it fits, you sits. That's not just a slogan ‚Äî it's a constitutional right. The Chairman's administration will ensure every resident has access to at least one (1) cardboard box of appropriate size. Amazon partnership pending. Jeff Bezos has not returned our calls but we did find his shoe.

üåô

3 AM Is Now a Protected Activity Hour

Noise ordinances between 2:45 AM and 4:15 AM will be suspended citywide. This window ‚Äî which the Chairman calls "The Witching Business" ‚Äî is when the most important work gets done. Running. Yelling. Staring at walls with purpose.

Meet the Candidate

Chairman Meow

üê±

Mr. Tiddles "Chairman Meow" Bassington III

Owner, BASSLINE Nightclub & Jazz Lounge
Mayoral Candidate (I) ‚Äî District At-Large

7
Years Old (49 Cat)
14 lb
Fighting Weight
0
Scandals*
2,847
Items Knocked Off Tables

*The dead bird on the porch in June 2023 was a gift, not a scandal.

Chairman Meow was born under a porch in the Eastside in 2019 to a feral mother and a father described by neighbors as "that huge orange one." Adopted at eight weeks by nightclub promoter Derek Bassington, the Chairman quickly demonstrated executive potential by claiming the highest surface in every room and refusing to move for anyone.

By 2021, the Chairman had effectively taken over operations at BASSLINE Nightclub & Jazz Lounge. Derek insists he is still the owner. Nobody who works there agrees. The Chairman's management style ‚Äî staring at employees until they do what he wants ‚Äî has resulted in a 340% increase in revenue and a 100% increase in mice removed from the premises.

When asked why he's running for mayor, the Chairman pushed a glass of water off the table and left the room. His campaign manager, a 22-year-old named Toby who "just kind of fell into this," interpreted this as "a bold rejection of the political establishment and a thirst for change."

The Chairman's platform emerged organically from his lived experience. "He naps 16 hours a day and runs a successful nightclub," Toby explains. "Imagine what he could do with a city." When pressed on whether a cat can legally hold office, Toby noted that "the city charter says 'any resident,' and he definitely lives here. He threw up on the voter registration form and we're counting that."

Chairman Meow is an independent. He has never belonged to any party. He has knocked a Republican and a Democrat off a shelf, but this was not a political statement ‚Äî they were simply in his spot.

He sat on my laptop for three hours and when he left, my taxes were done. I don't know how. I don't ask questions anymore.

Patricia Huang

Founder, BASSLINE Nightclub (technically still the owner)

He walked across my keyboard and accidentally submitted a zoning proposal that fixed the drainage issue on 4th Street. The city council approved it unanimously. It was better than anything we'd produced in nine years.

AN OPEN LETTER FROM THE WHISKER QUARTET

Day 341 of continuous performance ¬∑ Originally booked for "one set on a Friday"

To the voters of this city, to Chairman Meow, and to God, if He is listening over the alto sax:

We were hired on March 14, 2025 to play a single 45-minute set at BASSLINE Nightclub for a private party. When we attempted to leave, the Chairman sat in front of the door. We have not stopped playing since. We sleep in shifts. Our families send provisions on Tuesdays.

We are submitting the following demands through the only channel still available to us ‚Äî the candidate's own campaign website, which Toby forgot to password-protect:

  1. 01

    Dental insurance. Marcus has been playing bass with a cracked molar since June. He can only play in B-flat now. This is limiting our setlist to 11 songs.

  2. 02

    One (1) day off. We are not particular about which day. Any day. Even a holiday. We will take Arbor Day.

  3. 03

    The Chairman must stop sitting on the drum kit during ballads. It's not a commentary on our tempo. It's fur in the snare and it's affecting our sound.

  4. 04

    Payment for the last 7 months. We have invoiced $47,300. Campaign treasurer "Spreadsheet" has responded to every invoice by walking across the keyboard. We have received three payments of $0.00, one payment of $ggggggg, and a fax that was just a paw print.

  5. 05

    Please stop requesting "Caravan" at 3 AM. The Chairman does not request it verbally. He simply stares at our saxophonist until she plays it. It has been every night for 341 nights. Linda is losing her mind.

This section will remain on the website until our demands are met or until Toby figures out how to edit HTML. We estimate we have at least two more weeks. ‚Äî The Whisker Quartet, Local 802 (Involuntary Chapter)

Questions & Answers

Frequently Asked Questions

Can a cat legally run for mayor? +
We have consulted two attorneys on this matter. The first laughed for four minutes and then hung up. The second read the city charter aloud for 90 minutes and concluded: "It doesn't say he can't." We are running with that. The city charter requires candidates to be "a resident of the municipality for no fewer than 12 consecutive months." Chairman Meow has lived at BASSLINE since 2019 and has never once left voluntarily. The charter also requires candidates to "file a declaration of intent." The Chairman stepped on a form. Close enough.
What is the Chairman's position on the housing crisis? +
The Chairman believes every resident deserves a box. Not a metaphorical box. A literal cardboard box. His Universal Box Access program will provide free Amazon boxes to all residents. "Housing is about comfort," Toby explains. "Have you ever seen a cat in a box? That is peak contentment. That is what government should provide." When asked about mortgage rates, the Chairman knocked a pen off the table, which Toby interpreted as "bold fiscal reform."
Why are parts of the campaign's financial filings just keyboard spam? +
Campaign treasurer Spreadsheet (tabby, 4 years old, no relevant qualifications) has a habit of sitting on the campaign laptop, particularly when financial documents are open. We have tried: closing the laptop, buying a decoy laptop, placing a warm towel on a nearby chair, and begging. Spreadsheet has sat on all of these things. The FEC has been notified. Their response was, "Please stop calling us about this." We have filed an amended Q3 report seven times. Four of them just say "jjjjjjjjjjjjjjjj."
What about the jazz band situation? +
The Whisker Quartet was hired for one set. They are still playing. The Chairman sits in front of the exit whenever they attempt to leave. This is not a labor violation because, legally, he is a cat and does not have the capacity to "employ" anyone. The band disagrees. Their attorney also laughed for four minutes but is reportedly "looking into it." We consider the continuous live jazz to be a feature, not a bug. Morale at BASSLINE has never been higher. (Note: The Whisker Quartet disputes this claim.)
How do I volunteer for the campaign? +
Show up to BASSLINE any evening between 9 PM and 5 AM. You will be assessed by the Chairman personally (he will sniff your hand). If accepted, you will receive a campaign t-shirt and a role that Toby will invent on the spot. Current volunteer roles include: "Deputy Treat Liaison," "Assistant to the Nap Coordinator," and "The One Who Cleans Up When He Misses the Litter Box." We do not currently have a volunteer coordinator because the last one was "stared out of the building."
Is the Chairman's opponent, Mayor Jenkins, concerned? +
Mayor Jenkins held a press conference last week in which he called our campaign "a mockery of the democratic process." The Chairman was not present at this press conference because he was asleep on a radiator. Toby responded with a statement that read: "Mayor Jenkins is afraid of change. Chairman Meow is afraid of the vacuum. Only one of those fears is rational." Polls show Chairman Meow leading by 39 points among voters aged 18-34 and by 67 points among voters who describe themselves as "honestly just done with all of this."

In the News

Press Coverage

The Municipal Gazette ‚Äî Feb 8, 2026

Cat Leading Mayoral Race By 39 Points; City Council "Genuinely Unsure What To Do"

A new poll from Oakwood Research shows Chairman Meow, a 7-year-old tuxedo cat, commanding 67% of likely voters in the upcoming mayoral election. Mayor Jenkins (28%) called the results "statistically impossible" before being informed that the margin of error was ¬±2%. The remaining 5% of voters wrote in "laser pointer," which is not a registered candidate but does outperform Jenkins among independents.

Channel 4 Action News ‚Äî Jan 29, 2026

Nightclub Owner Cat's Campaign Rally Draws 4,000; Band "Not Here By Choice"

An estimated 4,000 supporters gathered at BASSLINE Nightclub for what the campaign called "the largest political rally in venue history." The Whisker Quartet provided entertainment, as they have every night for the past 11 months. Bassist Marcus Davis held up a sign during his solo that read "THIS IS NOT A RALLY FOR US. WE LIVE HERE NOW." Campaign manager Toby described the event as "electric."

Associated Press ‚Äî Jan 15, 2026

FEC Receives 7th Amended Filing From Cat's Campaign; "Entire Document Is The Letter J"

Federal Election Commission spokesperson Dana Reeves confirmed that the campaign of Chairman Meow has submitted its seventh amended Q3 financial filing, which she described as "nineteen pages of the letter J, a paw print on page 20, and a partially legible figure that might be $847.50 or might be $84,750." The campaign blamed its treasurer, a cat named Spreadsheet, who reportedly sat on the laptop for the duration of the filing process.

Opinion ‚Äî The Daily Standard

I Spent A Week Embedded With Chairman Meow's Campaign. I Have Never Been More Confused.

On day one, campaign manager Toby assured me the operation was "more organized than it looks." By day three, I watched the candidate push a $200 campaign donation off a table. By day five, the jazz band's saxophonist, Linda, asked me to smuggle a note to her husband. I did. It said, "Tell the kids I'm playing Caravan again tonight. I love them." The campaign is, against all evidence, winning.

Editorial Board ‚Äî City Herald

We Cannot In Good Conscience Endorse A Cat For Mayor. We Are Doing It Anyway.

The Herald's editorial board has endorsed every mayoral candidate since 1952 based on policy, experience, and civic vision. Chairman Meow has none of these. He has, however, submitted a zoning proposal (via keyboard) that accidentally solved the 4th Street drainage issue, stared down a city council member until she cried (she later described it as "the most honest conversation I've had in politics"), and maintained a nightclub with zero health code violations, which is more than the current mayor's office can say about City Hall.

BASSLINE Nightclub Incident Log ‚Äî Ongoing

Incident #247: Chairman Sat On Sound Board During Peak Hours

At approximately 11:47 PM on January 22, the Chairman positioned himself on the main sound board, adjusting the bass to a frequency that shattered two cocktail glasses and caused the drummer to play involuntarily faster. The resulting 20-minute drum-and-bass breakdown was described by attendees as "transcendent" and by staff as "a health and safety issue." No injuries. Three noise complaints. One marriage proposal.

BASSLINE Nightclub Incident Log ‚Äî Ongoing

Incident #251: Campaign Treasurer Submitted Invoice to Self, Approved It

Spreadsheet sat on the laptop while the accounts payable screen was open. The resulting keystrokes generated an invoice for $ggggggggg.gg payable to "hhhhhhhhhhh." The system auto-approved it because Spreadsheet was also sitting on the approval button. Toby discovered the transaction three days later and described his reaction as "a sound I have never made before." The bank flagged the transaction. We have been asked to open fewer tabs.

BASSLINE Nightclub Incident Log ‚Äî Ongoing

Incident #253: Jazz Band Attempted Escape Via Kitchen

At 4:12 AM, members of The Whisker Quartet were observed moving their instruments toward the kitchen exit. The Chairman, who had been asleep on the bar, woke up, crossed the room in approximately 0.8 seconds, and sat in front of the kitchen door. The band returned to the stage. Linda played the opening bars of "Caravan" unprompted. No one asked her to. She says she can't stop anymore.

üì¢ WHISKER QUARTET UNION NOTICE: Local 802 (Involuntary Chapter) meets every Tuesday at 4 AM between sets. Agenda items include: dental, the concept of "leaving," and whether Marcus's molar situation constitutes a workplace injury. All members must attend because all members are already here. Solidarity forever, or at least until someone figures out the door.
